model.name: Tokyo
model.description: Sure, everyone knows something about Tokyo: its grander-than-grand fish market, Tsukiji; its imperial palace, floating, dreamlike, in the center of the city; its extravagant street fashions that are, two decades on, still a source of inspiration to designers around the world. But although what we know about Tokyo is fascinating, colorful, and compelling enough, the city's real pleasures are in fact smaller and subtle...yet just as transporting. Explore a little and you'll quickly realize that beyond the neon, the bustle, and the technology is really a series of village-like neighborhoods, each with their own shrine or temple, traditional sweets shop and udon stands, and mom-and-pop stores—all connected by the best public transportation system in the world. So forget what you know: What you'll discover is the stuff you'll never forget.
model.seoName: Things to Do in Tokyo: A Conde Nast Traveler Guide
model.socialName: Tokyo City Guide: Where to Eat, Stay, and Play
model.dontMiss:
###Eat###

It’s almost the end of persimmon season in Japan. Forget what you think you know of the fruit: here, the sweet varietal has no bitter aftertaste, and is intensely sugary and a bit floral. Buy perfect examples at the food hall of any depachika, or department store.

###Art###


[#activity: /activities/53eae592976f8f2d44d58a87]|||It’s your last month to catch “Around Michel Gondry’s World,” a multimedia exhibit of the French director’s dreamy and inimitable universe, at the [Museum of Contemporary Art.](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/museum-of-contemporary-art-okyo) |||





###Stay###

[#hotel: /hotels/5493432dece808e916c32803]|||Tokyo has more excellent hotels than perhaps any other major city. Joining the league is the new (and long awaited) [Aman Tokyo](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/tokyo/aman-tokyo), occupying six floors of a new skyscraper in the city’s historic Otemachi district. We’re anticipating something special. 
|||





###Do###

[#activity: /activities/53eae595976f8f2d44d58a8d]|||New Year’s is the single most important holiday in Japan. On December 31 at 2pm, join the crowds (and there’ll be a lot of them) at [Meiji-jingu](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/meiji-jingu), one of the city’s most important shrines, who the biannual purification ceremony. You’ll get to take part in this timeless Shinto ritual. |||








###Eat###


[#activity: /activities/549465b3287bf30b36b41e1b]|||The Japanese imperial family is the oldest royal dynasty in the world. Every year on the emperor’s birthday—December 23—the inner gardens of the [Imperial Palace](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/tokyo-imperial-palace) are opened so the populace can come wish the emperor good health and a long life. The family makes three appearances: one at 10:20 am, one at 11 am, and one at 11:40am. |||

featuredEats.name: Katsukura
featuredEats.description: One of the best tonkatsu (deep-fried pork cutlet) kitchens in town, Katsukura also offers excellent side dishes like deep-fried shrimp, tofu-skin croquettes, tender stewed pork, savory egg custards, and fantastic Kyoto-style pickles. And unlike many Tokyo restaurants, they stay open all afternoon, which is very convenient if you've missed the usual lunch-hour window.
featuredEats.shortDescription: A deep-fried paradise, featuring some of the city's most delicious tonkatsu.

featuredEats.name: Takazawa
featuredEats.description: Meals don't get more intimate than at Takazawa, and not just because its dining room has only ten seats. Chef Yoshiaki Takazawa prepares his French dishes in full view of guests from a raised, stainless-steel platform. There's a clear Japanese spin on Takazawa's creations—the ratatouille, for example, resembles a sushi roll and is to be eaten in one bite, and most of the seasonal ingredients are sourced from Japan—but rather than the silent treatment encountered at most small restaurants in Tokyo, he makes the experience a welcoming one with the help of his cheerful servers and playful dishes. Diners have the option of a seven-, nine-, or eleven-course meal, but be prepared for a few surprises.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Enjoy inventive, French-inflected cuisine by chef Yoshiaki Takazawa in a warm, intimate setting.

featuredEats.name: Sushi Nakamura
featuredEats.description: The unassuming, Michelin-starred Sushi Nakamura is the ideal setting for sushi that suggests chamber music of the highest order: intimate, honest, and direct. The menu here is omakase, and along with a carefully paced selection of 12 or so pieces of sushi or sashimi—clam, lightly brushed with soy-lemon dressing and a sprinkle of sea salt, served on a mound of warm rice; rich, savory mackerel—you’ll be treated to a few cooked dishes, including, perhaps, braised bonito. Both the gracious staff—led by the restrained head chef, Masanori Nakamura—and the elegant, all-Japanese crowd contribute to a dining experience that feels both singular and timeless.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Head to Rappongi for Michelin-starred sushi at Masanori Nakamura's elegantly restrained spot.

featuredEats.name: Kyubei
featuredEats.description: Kyubei is known as the inventor of gunkan-maki ("battleship wrap"), the technique whereby sushi with a loose topping like fish roe is held together with a wraparound seaweed barrier. Despite the long history, Kyubei's chefs haven't been resting on their laurels—the fish here is still as good as it gets. Cuttlefish and abalone, items that often tend to be chewy, are incredibly tender here, while the egg custard is an inspiration. Even the little entr'acte morsels such as pickled eggplant are outstanding.
featuredEats.shortDescription: Don’t miss the gunkan-maki ("battleship wrap") sushi—the venerable 71-year-old shop invented it.

play.hed: 7 Wonderfully Weird Things to Do in Tokyo
play.dek: Say what you want about Tokyo—just don’t call it boring or predictable. There’s no shortage of things to do in the city, particularly when it comes to activities of a quirkier nature. Here’s a roundup of the weirdest and most wonderful experiences to be had in Japan’s capital.
play.seoTitle: 7 Wonderfully Weird Things to Do in Tokyo
play.seoDescription: Say what you want about Tokyo—just don’t call it boring or predictable.
play.socialTitle: 7 Wonderfully Weird Things to Do in Tokyo
play.socialDescription: Say what you want about Tokyo—just don’t call it boring or predictable.

items.title: Visit a Maid Cafe
items.caption: Japan’s growing fetish culture, along with its love for cosplay (a phenomenon where die-hard fans dress up as their favorite anime and comic book characters), have birthed the "maid cafe"—an establishment where waitresses prance around in maid costumes and play personal servant to patrons as though they were in a private home. The ladies, often of a younger persuasion, affect cutesy voices and gestures while tending to customers, addressing them as "Master" and "Mistress."  Along with typical cafe fare, the menu is adorned with a variety of "alternative" services, ranging from spoon-feeding to ear cleaning. I went to chain [Maidreamin](http://maidreamin.com/en) in Tokyo’s Akihibara district, but the popularity of these cafes means that they can be found all around the city.

items.title: Eat at Robot Restaurant
items.caption: Few experiences are more discombobulating than an evening at Tokyo’s [Robot Restaurant](http://www.robot-restaurant.com/E/), best described as a loud, colorful cabaret show that stretches your senses to their absolute limit. Starring scantily clad majorettes, an army of dancing 8-foot tall robots, and a soundtrack packed with hits from Broadway musicals (the theme from *Dreamgirls* was my personal favorite), a stop here is well worth your time.

items.title: Spot Freaky Fashions in Harajuku and Akihibara
items.caption: People-watching doesn’t get any better than in the neighborhoods of Harajuku and Akihibara, where enthusiastic fashionistas and cosplayers parade their finest get-ups on the city streets.  Staring isn’t rude, it’s requested—wannabe models flock to these districts on designated days and times specifically to show off. From extreme hairstyles to sky-high platform heels to funky onesies, these human mannequins provide a feast for the eyes (or an assault on them, depending on how you look at it).

items.title: Rock out to Dancehall Reggae Music at Garam
items.caption: I was both surprised and delighted to see my Jamaican culture proudly represented at [Garam](https://www.facebook.com/pages/Reggae-CLUB-Garam/115363385216385) in Shinjuku-ku, one of the many reggae nightclubs springing up around Tokyo.  The semi-underground movement has taken flight in recent years, propelled by music enthusiasts who may not be Caribbean by blood, but embody the spirit and good vibes.

items.title: Auction for Tuna at the Tsukiji Fish Market
items.caption: You may have seen a sumo match, but have you ever seen a live tuna auction? The [Tsukiji Fish Market](http://www.tsukiji-market.or.jp/tukiji_e.htm), one of the world’s largest fish markets, holds a 5 a.m. sell-off featuring lots of fish tossing and loud, rapid-fire Japanese from auctioneers and bidders alike. If a predawn visit to the exclusive first-come, first-serve event doesn’t suit you (only a maximum of 120 people per day are allowed in to watch), a spin around the market in the late morning is still an interesting thing to do.

items.title: Experience Shibuya Crossing
items.caption: A trek to Tokyo’s most famous intersection is more wonderful than weird. However, the seemingly infinite groups of people crossing the street in front of the Shibuya subway station is a jarring sight to behold. My tip? Park yourself on the third floor of the nearby Starbucks to get an unobstructed aerial view.

items.title: Stay in a Capsule Hotel
items.caption: After exploring quirky Tokyo, lay your tired body down in a capsule hotel (like the [Green Plaza Shinjuku](http://www.hgpshinjuku.jp/en/hotel/), pictured) and avail yourself of one of Japan’s most unique sleeping situations. [Claustrophobes beware](http://www.cntraveler.com/galleries/2014-09-09/cozy-or-claustrophobic-the-smallest-hotel-rooms-in-the-world/): "rooms" are very small—usually only just long and wide enough to fit the body. However, these pods have the advantage of being significantly cheaper than more conventional accommodation.

fields.name: Oneika Raymond
fields.shortBio: Oneika Raymond is an educator, writer, and travel junkie who chronicles her adventures abroad on her blog [Oneika the Traveller](http://www.oneika-the-traveller.com/).
fields.bio: Oneika Raymond is an educator, writer, and travel junkie who has travelled to 70 countries on 6 continents. She chronicles her adventures abroad on her blog, [Oneika the Traveller](http://www.oneika-the-traveller.com/), and has also been featured in a number of online publications including *National Geographic, Ebony,* and *The Huffington Post*. Originally from Canada, she is a serial expat who has lived in France, Mexico, Hong Kong, and the UK. A thrill-seeker who is always in the midst of planning her next trip, Oneika has, amongst other things, trekked in Nepal, sailed in Croatia, and gone on safari in Tanzania.

play.hed: 5 Common Mistakes Travelers Make in Japan
play.dek: Yuko Ehara, the Palace Hotel Tokyo's expert on manners, shares five of travelers’ most common mistakes—and what to do instead.
play.body:
With its baroque rituals and ancient traditions, Japanese etiquette strikes fear in the hearts of even seasoned travelers. But no need to worry: It’s effort—not execution—that matters most to the Japanese. “Everybody understands you’re from a different culture,” says Yuko Ehara, a Tokyo-based tour guide and etiquette expert. “If you make a sincere effort to learn, we are appreciative and forgiving of mistakes.” Now, the Palace Hotel Tokyo has launched Cultivating Tokyo, a series of private etiquette seminars to help business and leisure guests avoid faux pas (*81-3- 3211-5211; two-hour lessons from about $170*). We asked Ehara to share five of travelers’ most common mistakes—and what to do instead.


[#image: /photos/53fcea1f81424d9d655bcf9b]||||||








__1__. __Mistreating business cards.__ 

One’s business card is an extension of oneself. Accept (and offer) each card with two hands while facing the other person; then look at the card before putting it away.


[#image: /photos/53fcea1f81424d9d655bcf9c]||||||








__2.__ __Dipping the rice part of nigiri sushi into soy sauce.__


To avoid breaking up the rice, turn the sushi upside down and dip the fish into the sauce. Just do so sparingly—dousing sushi in soy sauce offends the chef.


[#image: /photos/53fcea2881424d9d655bcfb9]||||||








__3.__ __Sticking your chopsticks vertically into a bowl of rice.__ 

To Buddhists, this means you’re offering your rice to the dead. Instead, lay the chopsticks horizontally across the bowl or rest them on the ceramic holder provided.


[#image: /photos/53fe4c4ca5a7650f3959d96b]||||||





__4. Wrapping your kimono the wrong way.__ 

If you stay at a traditional Japanese inn, you might be given a *yukata*, or light cotton kimono. When you put it on, be sure to wrap the left side over the right; it’s done the opposite way only on corpses.


[#image: /photos/53fe4c7781424d9d655bd461]||||||





__5. Letting your bare feet touch the ground outside before entering a home.__ 

Japanese hosts often expect you to remove your shoes before you come inside. If you step on the ground with bare (or socked) feet, you’ll bring dirt in—and show disrespect to your host.

play.dek: Fishmongers, entrepreneurs, and street vendors all peddle their wares in Tokyo's YaNeSen, a historic neighborhood that feels far removed from the rest of the very modern city.
play.hed: Photos from the Road: A Stroll Through Tokyo's YaNeSen

items.caption: When the bright lights of Shinjuku wore me out, I headed to "YaNeSen," or the residential districts of Yanaka, Nezu, and Sendagi, where a Tokyo of yesteryear survives against all odds.
The main drag Yanaka Ginza, popular with Japanese travelers, hums with life.
Mom and pop stores share the street with popular eateries.
Many street vendors have served Japanese celebrities—and have photographs to prove it.
But the real action takes place in the alleyways, where young entrepreneurs have begun staking out the tiny storefronts.
It's not all just young'ns hawking retro goods. A traditional puppet theater in Yanaka attracts visitors of all ages.
Take off your shoes if you want to enter this cafe upstairs.
To soak up the atmosphere, take a lazy afternoon stroll and do plenty of (window) shopping with Tokyoites.
Must-have accoutrements on any Tokyo backstreet: potted plants.
Yanaka is home to a number of living room-sized bookstores, bars, cafes, and boutiques.
Small, unassuming eateries come alive at meal times.
Don't forget to check out what's behind the door.
[Sette](http://www.sette.jp/) stocks leather goods that the owner/craftswoman makes right in her showroom.
Even though I don't speak a lick of Japanese, I could spend hours sipping tea and browsing gorgeous picture books at [Ringoya](http://ringoya-galerie.com).
I also spent too much time wishing I could take back some of the used furniture I found in Sendagi's shops.
You can explore the area on foot—or, do as the Tokyoites do and get a bike.
Because much of the scenery is residential, the walk gave me a glimpse at residents' everyday lives.
Of course, you won't be the only one pointing a camera at these well-aged homes.
It's not unusual to find a designer shop flanked between a nondescript door and an old warehouse.
Operating out of a garage, [So An](http://www.y-soan.com) stocks items hand-knit in-house.
Paper goods and vintage toys are some of the souvenirs I found here.
But the new businesses haven't pushed out the neighborhood folks, such as this fishmonger.
Not to be outdone by the designers, even the rice store has a colorful storefront.
Don't be alarmed by the sudden bursts of colors between the more demure wooden homes.

pinterest.dek: With its artsy scene and abundance of quirky shops, Daikanyama is basically the Brooklyn of central Tokyo.

items.caption: I have roamed the globe quite a bit, living and working in some fantastic places, from Amsterdam to Singapore. But the unlikely spot that should be on all our bucket lists is Tokyo's quirky central neighborhood of Daikanyama. It is dense with small boutiques, open-air cafes, interesting bookstores, and good restaurants. Photographer [Rebecca Toh](http://rebeccatoh.com) shared some of her favorite local spots with me, capturing the neighborhood so authentically with her images. Let's start with Annon Cook, pictured here...

items.title: Annon Cook
items.caption: [Annon Cook](http://ambidex.co.jp/annon_cook/), a cafe serving healthy food with organic ingredients, is stashed away on Cat Street in Harajuku just above a clothing shop. But Daikanyama is full of gems, most of them quite visible on the surface, making this neighborhood an attractive place for a leisurely stroll.

items.title: Daikanyama T-Site
items.caption: One particularly popular attraction is [Daikanyama T-Site](http://tsite.jp/daikanyama/store-service/tsite-en.html), a modern bookstore featuring a lounge, cafe, and upscale convenience store. T-Site is named after the Tsutaya, a well-known CD/DVD rental shop (how retro). When you look closely at the storefront, you might recognize the interlocking T-shapes that subtly reference the logo of Tsutaya.

items.title: Journey
items.caption: With the modern T-site on our radar, it seems fitting to also visit something from the past. When its last owner left, this old 1940s house was reinforced with aseismic walls—not an unnecessary luxury in Japan, unfortunately. Today, there's a shop inside called [Journey](http://www.hrm.co.jp/journey/) that carries basics and accessories mainly imported from the U.S. The shop window acts as a little gallery space, displaying photos of Daikanyama from days past.

items.title: Art on Wheels
items.caption: Daikanyama basically has three major streets—including main drags Kyu-Yamate-dori and Hachiman-dori—with a maze of winding little roads in between. Expats enjoy living here, and for good reason. I love seeing the locals on their Tokyo bikes—art on wheels.

items.title: UES
items.caption: [UES Clothing](http://www.japaneseselvagejeans.com/index.html) is a cozy little atelier making the most perfect jeans. The brand name “UES” derives from “waste” in English, as Japanese people often reuse old clothes as dust cloths to extend their use. The company hopes that its customers will similarly use their products for as long as they last.

items.title: Matsunosuke
items.caption: Akiko Hirano’s baking studio, [Matsunosuke](http://www.matsunosukepie.com/about/en_about.html), is _the_ place to go for apple pie. My sense is that once you have tried it, your bicycle will automatically take you there every day of the week. Not surprisingly, Hirano has written multiple cookbooks and has been collaborating with Dean & Deluca for several years.

items.title: Le Cordon Blue
items.caption: The culinary institute [Le Cordon Blue](http://www.lecordonbleu.com/tokyo/home-en/en) has found its place right here in the Daikanyama neighborhood. Culinary Paris meets design haven Tokyo? That’s as good as it gets. While students are busy learning the craft of cooking, the guests can enjoy some pastries on the little outside terrace.

items.title: Bonjour Records
items.caption: With three outlets in the city, [Bonjour Records](http://www.bonjour.jp) is hard to miss, even if you get your bearings wrong. They have fashion, books, and music for the younger crowd and trend-seekers among us—think the _Marfa Journal_ and pocket tees—but it would be easy for anyone to walk away with a special souvenir.

items.title: Mocha Coffee
items.caption: Beans from Yemen, a narrow glass-sided space, and a few tables—that’s all you need to enjoy a quality cup of coffee. When you step inside [Mocha Coffee](http://mochacoffee.jp), you will feel the passion for the beverage from owner Hussein Ahmed and his Japanese wife.

fields.name: Irene Hoofs
fields.shortBio: [Bloesem Living](http://bloesem.blogs.com/) is where editor Irene Hoofs garners and shares ideas for design, for leisurely pursuits, and the art of traveling.
fields.bio:
Founder Irene Hoofs created Bloesem Blogs in December 2006. Leaving her hometown Amsterdam for the first time in 1997, she has enjoyed roaming the globe for a couple of years, making stopovers in London, New York, Toronto, and Kuala Lumpur. A banker turned graphic designer, she sold her work through BARNEYS NY and Selfridges&Co. Irene lives online, but on quieter days you will find her behind her weaving machine, experimenting with crafts or making jewelry. She has a passion for designs from the "olden days", as her eldest puts it. When it comes to vintage finds, friends refer to Irene as the gatherer. Today she lives in Singapore with her husband Rik and their two sons, Lode and Kiet. Bloesem Living and Bloesem Kids is where she garners and shares ideas for design, for leisurely pursuits, for creating soul-soothing interiors, for love of the handmade, for vintage appreciation, and for the art of traveling. Her vision is to be an online reference where readers come as a resource for beauty and imagination, in a moment of repose and relaxation.

Just recently, Irene opened the doors to a concept store in one of Singapore's upcoming neighborhoods, Tiong Bahru. Here you can shop for unique design pieces from all over the world or follow one of the creative workshops Bloesem organizes.

pinterest.dek: David Coggins, a lifelong student and collector of mid-century Americana, makes a pilgrimage to Tokyo and discovers a city where the old-fashioned martini and RFK-era suit are not just being revived but remastered.
pinterest.seoDescription: David Coggins, a lifelong student and collector of mid-century Americana, makes a pilgrimage to Tokyo and discovers a city where the old-fashioned martini and RFK-era suit are not just being revived but remastered.
pinterest.socialDescription: David Coggins, a lifelong student and collector of mid-century Americana, makes a pilgrimage to Tokyo and discovers a city where the old-fashioned martini and RFK-era suit are not just being revived but remastered.
pinterest.body:
[#image: /photos/53f4ca4213e72ede281a9db9]||||||





Anyone who's ever worn a pair of jeans knows that Levi Strauss may have invented jeans but the Japanese perfected them. Where would we be, really, without their 1990s-era embrace of selvedge denim?

But the truth is that the Japanese’s fascination with mid-century Americana goes far beyond jeans. This fixation is, depending on how you look at it, either perfectly understandable or just a little perverse: America, after all, occupied Japan from 1945 to 1952, following the country’s defeat in World War II. It was a disorienting period of recalibration for the Japanese, who lost not only the war but, for a period, their sense of self—something they wouldn’t recover until the 1960s, when the country underwent its startling transformation to modernity (and then, in the ’80s, hyper-modernity).

What’s inarguable, however, is that the Japanese have always been obsessives . . . and what’s more, once they become obsessed with something, they invariably improve upon it: a lesson that style writer and professional bon vivant David Coggins learned decades ago, as a freshly minted college graduate, on his first of many visits to Japan. “I’ve always collected classic men’s clothes,” says Coggins, who’s a creative consultant for Freemans, the New York City–based fantasyland of men’s style. “I actually bought shoes—without even knowing if they’d fit—from Douglas Fairbanks, Jr.’s estate auction.” But in Tokyo, Coggins discovered people whose dedication to American nostalgia eclipsed even his own—be they vintage-store owners selling beautifully preserved World War II Army jackets or tailors dedicating themselves to re-creating the perfect RFK-era sack suit. And so we asked him to share with us his favorite time-travel destinations in Tokyo: places where even the most die-hard nostalgist would find himself wondering if he hadn’t, somehow, traveled back in time.


[#image: /photos/53f4ca40e8207d14440fa4d4]||||||


##Orchid Bar

When the Okura Hotel opened on the edge of Roppongi in 1962, it was a modernist sensation: Designed by architect Yoshiro Taniguchi, it quickly became a symbol of the country’s leap into the postwar decades of rapid wealth and globalization. Today, the Okura is a luxury hotel, but despite the changes visited on both the hotel and the city, its iconic [Orchid Bar](http://cnt.conde.io/bars/tokyo/orchid-bar) remains untouched. With its low ceilings, wood accents, and discreet stained glass panels, the Orchid—which has just 15 bar seats—still recalls a more civilized age of travel. But aside from the soothing atmosphere, the real reason to come here is the whiskey. The entry to the bar takes you past a series of 20-odd glass lockers stocked with longtime customers’ extraordinary collections (I saw a bottle of 1971 Macallan, which might fetch $10,000—if you can find one for sale), and once seated, you can order whiskey of varying ages: a 17-year-old Hibiki, one of Japan’s finest, is about $20. [#image: /photos/53f4ca4013e72ede281a9da8]||||||


##Sushi Nakamura

The unassuming, Michelin-starred [ Sushi Nakamura](http://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/tokyo/sushi-nakamura)  is behind an understated sliding door in the bar-crowded Roppongi district. Outside, the streets are lively and noisy, but inside this dim, hushed space—its gorgeous cypress bar seats just 11—you feel miles away. It’s the ideal setting for sushi that suggests chamber music of the highest order: intimate, honest, and direct. The menu here is omakase, and along with a carefully paced selection of 12 or so pieces of sushi or sashimi—clam, lightly brushed with soy-lemon dressing and a sprinkle of sea salt, served on a mound of warm rice; rich, savory mackerel—you’ll be treated to a few cooked dishes, including, perhaps, braised bonito. ##Franklin Tailored
Since the 1960s, Tokyoites have had a highly cultivated taste for traditional American Ivy League dress; indeed, you’ll see examples of this around Tokyo, where men of all ages favor seersucker, herringbone, or pinstripes. “The Japanese well understand that Ivy style is a classic look which has stood the test of time,” says Patricia Mears, deputy director of the Museum at FIT in New York and curator of the 2012 FIT exhibition “Ivy Style.” Now, however, the Japanese aren’t just tracking down original tweed jackets and Levi’s—they’re making their own masterpieces. [#image: /photos/53f4ca43e8207d14440fa4e4]||||||





##Caid Modern Tailoring

[#image: /photos/53daa87f6dec627b149f9971]||||||

** You can't leave Tokyo without eating…**



 Soba (buckwheat noodles). In fact, you'll have a tough time leaving Japan without eating it at least once. Order a tempura lunch set (and you will, every day), and your tray comes piled high with cold, snappy noodles. Tokyo is sweltering and humid come summer, but a plate of chilled soba, often served with ice cubes mixed in, is the next best thing to climbing into the ice cream freezer at 7-Eleven.







**How to eat it**: Do not wear a white shirt. Your soba will be delivered to the table on a _zaru_ (bamboo tray), often with _nori_ (dried seaweed) sprinkled on top. Next to it will be a small cup of _tsuyu_ (a cold broth made from dried bonito flakes and soy sauce), an empty cup, a saucer with wasabi, and finely chopped _negi_ (scallion). Mix the tsuyu, wasabi, and negi in the cup; if you aren't used to spicy, go easy on the wasabi. If you're congested, it will clear you right up. Deftly use your chopsticks to pick up some soba noodles and then dip—don’t drown—your soba in the tsuyu. Lean over, open wide, and slurp heartily.







When you’ve nearly finished your soba, the waitstaff will bring over what looks like a lacquer teapot. It’s actually water from the pot in which the noodles where cooked. Hardcore soba lovers will pour it into their remaining tsuyu and drink it like soup.





[#image: /photos/53daa87fdcd5888e145c34a9]||||||

**How to order**: Like so many Japanese foods, this one is easy to order because its English name is Japanese. The menu will likely be in Japanese. Soba is often served as part of set meals, but if you want to order it a la carte, ask for "_zaru soba, onegai shimasu_" (“cold soba, please”). As soba broth is fish based, strict vegetarians will want to substitute soy sauce. Don't complicate things by trying to pantomime swapping soba broth for soy sauce, though; the soy sauce will already be on the table.







**How to pay**: The bill will be set discretely on your table after your order is relayed to the kitchen, but in the world's most polite country, this is in no way an attempt to rush you out of the restaurant. When you're ready to leave, just go to the cashier.







**Do you tip?** Tipping is not customary in Japan. If you leave money on the table, the waitstaff will try to give it back to you. Your polite thank you's throughout the meal are enough.



**Etiquette tip**: Leaning over your bowl and slurping the soba noisily is perfectly acceptable. You should inhale with gusto to cool down the noodles on their way from the plate to your mouth. Try not to cut the noodles with your teeth, and be careful not to let them slip from your mouth and splash back into the bowl. Do not douse your entire tray of soba with soy sauce; this is what the empty cup is for.











**More travel etiquette**:



[The One Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







[What Not to Do in Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/what-not-to-do-in-las-vegas)



[What Not to Do in New York City](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/new-york/2013/12/what-not-to-do-nyc-travel)



_Sophie Friedman is a manager with [Context Travel walking tours](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists/paul-bennett), a company chosen as one of [Condé Nast Traveler's top travel specialists](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists)._

shop.dek: With its artsy scene and abundance of quirky shops, Daikanyama is basically the Brooklyn of central Tokyo.

items.caption: I have roamed the globe quite a bit, living and working in some fantastic places, from Amsterdam to Singapore. But the unlikely spot that should be on all our bucket lists is Tokyo's quirky central neighborhood of Daikanyama. It is dense with small boutiques, open-air cafes, interesting bookstores, and good restaurants. Photographer [Rebecca Toh](http://rebeccatoh.com) shared some of her favorite local spots with me, capturing the neighborhood so authentically with her images. Let's start with Annon Cook, pictured here...

items.title: Annon Cook
items.caption: [Annon Cook](http://ambidex.co.jp/annon_cook/), a cafe serving healthy food with organic ingredients, is stashed away on Cat Street in Harajuku just above a clothing shop. But Daikanyama is full of gems, most of them quite visible on the surface, making this neighborhood an attractive place for a leisurely stroll.

items.title: Daikanyama T-Site
items.caption: One particularly popular attraction is [Daikanyama T-Site](http://tsite.jp/daikanyama/store-service/tsite-en.html), a modern bookstore featuring a lounge, cafe, and upscale convenience store. T-Site is named after the Tsutaya, a well-known CD/DVD rental shop (how retro). When you look closely at the storefront, you might recognize the interlocking T-shapes that subtly reference the logo of Tsutaya.

items.title: Journey
items.caption: With the modern T-site on our radar, it seems fitting to also visit something from the past. When its last owner left, this old 1940s house was reinforced with aseismic walls—not an unnecessary luxury in Japan, unfortunately. Today, there's a shop inside called [Journey](http://www.hrm.co.jp/journey/) that carries basics and accessories mainly imported from the U.S. The shop window acts as a little gallery space, displaying photos of Daikanyama from days past.

items.title: Art on Wheels
items.caption: Daikanyama basically has three major streets—including main drags Kyu-Yamate-dori and Hachiman-dori—with a maze of winding little roads in between. Expats enjoy living here, and for good reason. I love seeing the locals on their Tokyo bikes—art on wheels.

items.title: UES
items.caption: [UES Clothing](http://www.japaneseselvagejeans.com/index.html) is a cozy little atelier making the most perfect jeans. The brand name “UES” derives from “waste” in English, as Japanese people often reuse old clothes as dust cloths to extend their use. The company hopes that its customers will similarly use their products for as long as they last.

items.title: Matsunosuke
items.caption: Akiko Hirano’s baking studio, [Matsunosuke](http://www.matsunosukepie.com/about/en_about.html), is _the_ place to go for apple pie. My sense is that once you have tried it, your bicycle will automatically take you there every day of the week. Not surprisingly, Hirano has written multiple cookbooks and has been collaborating with Dean & Deluca for several years.

items.title: Le Cordon Blue
items.caption: The culinary institute [Le Cordon Blue](http://www.lecordonbleu.com/tokyo/home-en/en) has found its place right here in the Daikanyama neighborhood. Culinary Paris meets design haven Tokyo? That’s as good as it gets. While students are busy learning the craft of cooking, the guests can enjoy some pastries on the little outside terrace.

items.title: Bonjour Records
items.caption: With three outlets in the city, [Bonjour Records](http://www.bonjour.jp) is hard to miss, even if you get your bearings wrong. They have fashion, books, and music for the younger crowd and trend-seekers among us—think the _Marfa Journal_ and pocket tees—but it would be easy for anyone to walk away with a special souvenir.

items.title: Mocha Coffee
items.caption: Beans from Yemen, a narrow glass-sided space, and a few tables—that’s all you need to enjoy a quality cup of coffee. When you step inside [Mocha Coffee](http://mochacoffee.jp), you will feel the passion for the beverage from owner Hussein Ahmed and his Japanese wife.

fields.name: Irene Hoofs
fields.shortBio: [Bloesem Living](http://bloesem.blogs.com/) is where editor Irene Hoofs garners and shares ideas for design, for leisurely pursuits, and the art of traveling.
fields.bio:
Founder Irene Hoofs created Bloesem Blogs in December 2006. Leaving her hometown Amsterdam for the first time in 1997, she has enjoyed roaming the globe for a couple of years, making stopovers in London, New York, Toronto, and Kuala Lumpur. A banker turned graphic designer, she sold her work through BARNEYS NY and Selfridges&Co. Irene lives online, but on quieter days you will find her behind her weaving machine, experimenting with crafts or making jewelry. She has a passion for designs from the "olden days", as her eldest puts it. When it comes to vintage finds, friends refer to Irene as the gatherer. Today she lives in Singapore with her husband Rik and their two sons, Lode and Kiet. Bloesem Living and Bloesem Kids is where she garners and shares ideas for design, for leisurely pursuits, for creating soul-soothing interiors, for love of the handmade, for vintage appreciation, and for the art of traveling. Her vision is to be an online reference where readers come as a resource for beauty and imagination, in a moment of repose and relaxation.

Just recently, Irene opened the doors to a concept store in one of Singapore's upcoming neighborhoods, Tiong Bahru. Here you can shop for unique design pieces from all over the world or follow one of the creative workshops Bloesem organizes.

[#image: /photos/53da95976dec627b149f4780]||||||

It's no secret that Tokyo is a [shopping mecca](http://www.cntraveler.com/cities/tokyo/my-five/tokyo-shopping). But without proper guidance, you and your credit card will be lost. To help steer you to the coolest stores in Tokyo, we sat down with Gildas Loaëc and Masaya Kuroki, co-founders of Parisian-chic fashion and music label [Maison Kitsuné](http://kitsune.fr/). The duo have been traveling to Tokyo for years, and these are their picks for the city's best cafés and boutiques.










## Café Kitsune Tokyo
[#image: /photos/53da95976dec627b149f4782]||||||

"It's Maison Kitsuné coffee served up by Japan's finest baristas. There is also a curated selection of Maison Kitsuné clothing, accessories and compilations. 



The space features an authentic Japanese design, with low ceilings everywhere and organic materials. This café will also soon have [a little brother in Paris](http://www.kitsune.fr/journal/2014/01/events/cafe-kitsune-opening-in-paris-january-17th/), under the arcades of the Palais-Royal." _(3-17-1 Minami Aoyama, Minato-ku)_






















## [Kolor](http://kolor.jp)


"The founder and designer of Kolor, Mr. Junichi Abe has been slowly but steadily developing his menswear line since 2004. I have always been a fan of his aesthetic. He has the most beautiful store in Aoyama." _(B1, 5-6-10, Minami Aoyama, Minato-ku)_


## [Ron Herman](http://ronherman.jp)
[#image: /photos/53da9597dcd5888e145be271]||||||

"This store is the Japanese version of the famous Ron Herman outlet in California.



The aesthetic of the store is very spacious, easy to navigate, and kid-friendly—which is rare in Japan. I found these cute skateboards there the other day." _(2-11-1 Sendagaya, Shibuya-ku)_


































## [Julien David](http://juliendavid.com)


"Julien David is a hot new French designer. He is presenting in Paris for Fashion Week but lives in Tokyo, which is very original. He has a crazy little store in Jingumae near Omotesando. When I visited him before Christmas he offered me some chocolates." _ (2-7-15 Jingumae Shibuya-ku)_










## [N Hoolywood](http://n-hoolywood.tumblr.com)
[#image: /photos/53da9597dcd5888e145be26f]||||||

"This is my favorite store out of all the stores in the world. It has an incredible Louisiana-style design, with potpourri scent from Santa Maria Novella and the most stylish staff.



I once found a beautiful pink flannel shirt there. I was lucky since Japanese sizing only goes up to a medium and is not very easy to fit in!" _(4-13-16 Jingumae, Shibuya-ku)_

Anyone who's ever worn a pair of jeans knows that Levi Strauss may have invented jeans but the Japanese perfected them. Where would we be, really, without their 1990s-era embrace of selvedge denim?

But the truth is that the Japanese’s fascination with mid-century Americana goes far beyond jeans. This fixation is, depending on how you look at it, either perfectly understandable or just a little perverse: America, after all, occupied Japan from 1945 to 1952, following the country’s defeat in World War II. It was a disorienting period of recalibration for the Japanese, who lost not only the war but, for a period, their sense of self—something they wouldn’t recover until the 1960s, when the country underwent its startling transformation to modernity (and then, in the ’80s, hyper-modernity).

What’s inarguable, however, is that the Japanese have always been obsessives . . . and what’s more, once they become obsessed with something, they invariably improve upon it: a lesson that style writer and professional bon vivant David Coggins learned decades ago, as a freshly minted college graduate, on his first of many visits to Japan. “I’ve always collected classic men’s clothes,” says Coggins, who’s a creative consultant for Freemans, the New York City–based fantasyland of men’s style. “I actually bought shoes—without even knowing if they’d fit—from Douglas Fairbanks, Jr.’s estate auction.” But in Tokyo, Coggins discovered people whose dedication to American nostalgia eclipsed even his own—be they vintage-store owners selling beautifully preserved World War II Army jackets or tailors dedicating themselves to re-creating the perfect RFK-era sack suit. And so we asked him to share with us his favorite time-travel destinations in Tokyo: places where even the most die-hard nostalgist would find himself wondering if he hadn’t, somehow, traveled back in time.


[#image: /photos/53f4ca40e8207d14440fa4d4]||||||


##Orchid Bar

When the Okura Hotel opened on the edge of Roppongi in 1962, it was a modernist sensation: Designed by architect Yoshiro Taniguchi, it quickly became a symbol of the country’s leap into the postwar decades of rapid wealth and globalization. Today, the Okura is a luxury hotel, but despite the changes visited on both the hotel and the city, its iconic [Orchid Bar](http://cnt.conde.io/bars/tokyo/orchid-bar) remains untouched. With its low ceilings, wood accents, and discreet stained glass panels, the Orchid—which has just 15 bar seats—still recalls a more civilized age of travel. But aside from the soothing atmosphere, the real reason to come here is the whiskey. featuredShops.name: Mitsukoshi
featuredShops.description: Don't leave Tokyo without seeing the basement food hall of a local department store, known as a depachika. The depachika at Mitsukoshi's Ginza branch is one of the best and takes up a couple of floors. It has the atmosphere of a street market, with vendors hawking their wares at full voice. If you're not on the hunt for fresh fish or meat, there are also scores of counters selling Japanese cakes, sweets, and green tea, all perfectly wrapped and presented. Rice crackers—or senbei—make great (and easily packed) gifts.
featuredShops.shortDescription: The multi-floored basement food hall of this local department store is a can't miss experience.

featuredShops.name: Matsuya Ginza
featuredShops.description: Matsuya department store is worth a visit on its own, but the added attraction is the Design Collection and gallery on the seventh floor. The gallery sells a selection of the best in contemporary and classic wares, as chosen by the Japan Design Committee, with a focus on homegrown goods—particularly kitchen and tableware by the great Sori Yanagi, Japan's best-known product designer. There are also interesting art and design exhibitions.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Highlight on the gallery which sell a selection of the best in contemporary and classic wares.

featuredShops.name: Tokyu Hands Shibuya
featuredShops.description: Tokyu Hands defies description, but it is one of the city's most useful addresses. The ultimate hardware store, it sells everything from timber and flooring to stationery, luggage, kitchen equipment, camping gear, toiletries, and bathroom accessories. It even has a department for fancy dress costumes. Allow at least an hour at this Tokyo institution to peruse every floor. It's all immaculately laid out, and the staff—all wearing aprons—will do their best to help you navigate.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Set aside time to hit every floor at this hardware store on steroids.

featuredShops.name: Omotesando Hills
featuredShops.description: Omotesando Hills is as good a place as any to begin a fashion—and architecture—tour of the Aoyama neighborhood. Architect Tadao Ando's 366,000-square-foot development, which opened in February 2006, is a minimalist's fantasy mall, and unlike Tokyo's much larger luxury malls, which can be overwhelming, Omotesando Hills feels exclusive and manageable in both its gorgeous design and its choice offerings. From here you can stroll the tree-lined Omotesando Boulevard past boutiques of big-name Japanese designers like Yohji Yamamoto, Comme des Garçons, and Issey Miyake, and imports like Tod's, Gucci, Louis Vuitton, and Marc Jacobs.
featuredShops.shortDescription: Tour Omotesando Hills for the best fashion and architecture in the Aoyama neighborhood.

featuredStays.name: Palace Hotel Tokyo
featuredStays.description: An iconic sixties hotel buffed by a three-year restoration, in the tony Marunouchi district. The 290-room granite-and-glass structure peers over the moats of the Imperial Palace. Magisterial on the outside, with grand interiors (double-high ceilings, double-wide walkways) and a palette inspired by a spring kimono (the plush lobby carpet is a soft pistachio).
featuredStays.shortDescription: Start your day with a moat-side breakfast at this 290-room hotel that overlooks the Imperial Palace.

featuredStays.name: The Peninsula Tokyo
featuredStays.description: Built of amber Namibian granite, this property garners a pair of perfect scores. The two-story lobby has ivory walls and wooden lattices, and the 1,313-bulb concave chandelier resembles a swarm of fireflies. Rooms have bedside curtain controls, red-lacquered Japanese desks, horse chestnut sliding doors, and ceilings that are either painted gold or made of panels of handwoven cedar reeds. The granite and cherrywood bathrooms with large soaking tubs are designed to re-create the ambience of an onsen (with the modern concession of nail polish dryers). Rice paper shoji screens in spa treatment rooms allow for privacy while letting light filter in. According to our readers: "The Peninsula is a delight for all of the senses."
featuredStays.shortDescription: Beautifully furnished, wonderfully spacious rooms and large soaking tubs are the draw here.

featuredStays.name: Park Hyatt Tokyo
featuredStays.description: The Park Hyatt may be a 15-minute stroll from Shinjuku station (the hub for the west side of the city), but you’ll savor the quiet it offers. The hotel, which sits on the 41st through 48th floors of an office tower, is known for its hushed interiors, impeccable service, excellent Japanese breakfasts, and gorgeous enclosed rooftop pool, with views to Mount Fuji.
featuredStays.shortDescription: Come for the spectacular views of Mount Fuji, the magnificent rooftop pool, and the glorious quiet.

featuredStays.name: Conrad Tokyo
featuredStays.description: Set in the port area of Shiodome, this skyscraper is just south of the Ginza shopping area and a five-minute walk from the Tsukiji fish market. Employing traditional lantern-style lamps, bolsters with floral-patterned fabric, and Japanese brush painting in the headboards and flooring, "rooms are befitting of any five-star property and have spectacular views of Tokyo Bay." With two Gordon Ramsay restaurants and "a bar rivaling the New York Bar at the Park Hyatt," "this hotel is really worth the splurge." "Staff are always there to help but are not in your face like at some other top hotels in the city."
featuredStays.shortDescription: A hotel that embodies what you dream about when you think of Tokyo.

related.hed: The High-Speed Train Trip from Tokyo to Take Now
related.dek: A new extension of Japan's bullet train connects Tokyo to the West Coast city of Kanazawa, Japan—here's what to see and do in the charming, quiet city.
related.seoTitle: Kanazawa: The High-Speed Train Trip from Tokyo to Take Now
related.socialTitle: The High-Speed Train Trip from Tokyo to Take Now

items.caption: The Hokuriku Shinkansen, Japan’s high speed railway, just began service between Tokyo and [Kanazawa](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa), located on the West Coast of the main island Honshu. This enchanting city is often bypassed by tourists in favor of visiting Kyoto, but now it's just a bullet train ride away.
Bordered by the wildness of the coast to the West and the quiet beauty of the mountains to East, Kanazawa is an utterly modern city with an ancient heart.

In the heart of downtown, steps away from the popular shopping district of the Korinbo (which is home to stores like Chanel and Luis Vuitton), is the 200-year-old [Omi Cho Market](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/food), originally built during the Edo Period. The market has hundreds of vendors selling all sorts of delicacies from the Sea of Japan. While the star of the show is the snow crab, be sure to try the oysters shucked fresh and served with radish, spring onions, soy sauce, and lemon juice.  If you’re adventurous, grilled eel innards make a tasty snack.

To really experience the seamless blend of old and new that is so typical of Kanazawa, head to the Teramachi or Temple District east of the Saigawa River. Its [quiet streets](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/streets) give you a glimpse into everyday life, and there are ancient Shinto and Buddhist shrines at every turn.

Kanazawa was ruled by the powerful Maeda clan for two centuries before becoming famous for its [art and crafts](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/craft) during the Edo Period, especially its pottery. Tucked away on a side street in the Temple District on Nomachi is also the last remaining working kiln in Kanazawa, the 140-year-old, family run Kosen Kiln.

Kanazawa’s most famous potter-artist might be Toshio Ohi, a 14th-generation artist whose ancestors arrived in Kanazawa by initiation of the Maedas in 1666 to produce [delicate pottery](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/lookbook) for tea ceremonies. Today, Toshio Ohio utilizes age-old techniques to produce modern pieces of art.

Not far from the Ohi Gallery is the [Higashi-Chaya Geisha District,](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/streets) and as the sun sets, there’s nothing more romantic than walking through the stone streets lined with worn wooden teahouses. It is one of the oldest working Geisha districts in the country, and if you’re lucky, you’ll happen upon one of these beauties whose name literally translates to “art-doer”.

Kanazawa is also a gateway to the unexplored, wild [Noto Peninsula](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/noto-peninsula). The legendary Koshi Road winds its way through this windswept remote sliver of land. It was once only trodden by *Yamabushi*, Japanese aesthetics and mystics on the search for solitude. Today the road is paved and much easier to access.

While this little stunningly beautiful peninsula is the perfect place to enjoy breathtaking scenery, it’s also worth the trip to [Wajima](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/food), a fishing town that’s famous for its morning market and exquisite [lacquerware](http://www.projectbly.com/destinations/kanazawa/craft).

fields.shortBio: [Project Bly](http://www.projectbly.com/) is a travel and design website built on the philosophy that to know a city you must wander its streets. It features all things street, including street art, street food, and street markets.
fields.bio: Rena Thiagarajan is the founder of [Project Bly](http://www.projectbly.com/). She's a top-notch bazaar bargainer with a passion for textiles and has traveled to over 50 countries.

related.hed: Make This Your First (or Last) Meal in Tokyo
related.dek: Whether you’re on your way to the airport or just leaving it, these are the restaurants right nearby that make travel worth the trip. This week: eel near the transportation hub of Tokyo City Air Terminal.
related.seoTitle: Where to Eat Near Tokyo City Air Terminal
related.seoDescription: Whether you’re on your way to the airport or just leaving it, these are the restaurants right nearby that make travel worth the trip. This week: eel near the transportation hub of Tokyo City Air Terminal.
related.socialTitle: Make This Your First (or Last) Meal in Tokyo
related.socialDescription: Whether you’re on your way to the airport or just leaving it, these are the restaurants right nearby that make travel worth the trip.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/55071fbfa15a49046da9910a]||||||



**The Hub:** Tokyo City Air Terminal

**The Bite:** Izumoya's grilled eel bowl

**How to get there:** From Tokyo City Air Terminal, or T-CAT, take the Hanzomon line to Mitsukoshimae Station.

**Why we love it:** Right near the station and across the street from the Bank of Japan sits the legendary [Izumoya](http://www.idumoya.com/) restaurant *(3-3-4 Honkokucho, Nihonbashi, Chuo-ku tel: 03-3241-2476),* which specializes in grilled eel served over rice. The crowd is mostly Japanese, all getting in their eel fix before their flight (or right after it).  

Entrees vary in size, but you can’t go wrong with the basic unadon (about $16), which comes in a bento box full of rice, although eel aficionados should go for the Una Jyu Matsu (about $37), which has a higher-grade cut of fish. 


[#image: /photos/55071e44481a91bb7819f030]||||||



After eating, do a little souvenir shopping. Mitsukoshimae means “in front of Mitsukoshi,” Japan’s foremost luxury department store, where you can find gourmet food gifts of traditional sweets and sushi. This is the place to stock up on cookies from Yokumoku (the cigar cookies are a favorite) and tea from Ippudo (the green tea powder is a must) for yourself or as gifts to take with you on your trip. There's even an Izumoya eat-in and takeout shop here for those who love their eel on the run.

related.hed: The Easiest Way to Tour Tokyo's Best Ramen Shops
related.dek: How do you eat like a local in Tokyo even if you don't know a word of the language? The trick, I learned while recently planning a trip to Japan, is to hire a local expert, an unofficial ambassador who will take you to his or her favorite *izakayas*, ramen shops, and sushi bars. For about $100 an hour, you'll have a local fixer—more a plugged-in friend than a traditional tour guide—who will escort you to places you'd never find on your own.
related.socialTitle: The Easiest Way to Tour Tokyo's Best Ramen Shops

items.caption:
So how do you find these experts? Most are too low-profile for TripAdvisor, so instead I turned to Tokyo-focused food blogs through which experts share their discoveries—and brag about their credentials. I considered an afternoon with Yukari Sakamoto, [a food writer](http://foodsaketokyo.com/) and [one-time contributor to Condé Nast Traveler](http://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2013-06-18/tokyo), and with Shinji Nohara, who [was Anthony Bourdain's Tokyo fixer.](http://www.tokyofixer.com/) But the tour I booked was with [Brian MacDuckston](http://www.ramenadventures.com/), a self-described "ramen hunter" who has reviewed nearly 900 shops for [his blog](http://www.ramenadventures.com/) over the past eight years. (Only 100 of them have been "stinkers," he says.)

While I had no way to know for sure that my tour with MacDuckston would be exactly what I was looking for, reading his blog ahead of time gave me confidence that we'd be a good fit. Here's how our afternoon played out.

MacDuckston, an American whose other job is teaching English at a Japanese beauty school, met me at my hotel and then we went to one of his favorite ramen shops nearby. He does all the ordering—in Japanese, of course—while sharing some history on ramen culture.

Could you save some money by simply reading MacDuckston's blog and mapping out his favorites? Sure, but you'd miss some context. At our first stop, during a 45-minute wait, MacDuckston explained line etiquette. "Please wait behind the black and yellow cones," this sign reads. "Don't be noisy. Please move forward. There's a bathroom inside."

Once inside Kagari, in the upscale Ginza neighborhood, we tried the featured ramen, a creamy chicken broth with fresh seasonal vegetables, including Burdock root and bamboo shoots. There are only eight seats, and the line snaked down an alley. In other words: There’s no lingering. "They *will* yell 'hurry up'," MacDuckston says.

We hopped on the subway to our second stop, Kikanbo, in the Kanda neighborhood, which MacDuckston described as "salaryman town." Here, we waited for seats while hovering just behind businessmen slurping the specialty spicy ramen.
Some ramen shops come equipped with ordering machines, and here too MacDuckston had expert advice: When in doubt, “you should always go with top left," he says. "It's usually the specialty."

How should you eat your ramen? MacDuckston recommends slurping the noodles with chopsticks and *then* scooping the broth. It's the preferred method for most *ramen otaku*, or ramen nerds, because the technique keeps the noodles from getting soggy, he says.

While ramen guides will take you to as many spots as you'd like, most people, including me, hit their limit after two. To help digest, MacDuckston recommends ending the afternoon with a cool oolong tea. For 15,000 yen (about $126) all in, I thought the tour was a great value—and something I never would’ve been able to arrange on my own.

related.hed: What to Do in Tokyo: The Dior Guide
related.dek: Traveling to Japan is already a big enough deal (fresh sushi, Comme des Garçons around every corner, fresh sushi...). But when you get the opportunity to do so on Dior’s itinerary, well, it’s kind of a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
related.body:
[#image: /photos/54b9712b040ea11752369dcd]||||||



When the storied French house flies you to Tokyo, they really take care to show you a time. And now we’re sharing Dior's favorite spots with you:

__[The Imperial Palace and Gardens](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/tokyo-imperial-palace)__

The Imperial Palace and Gardens is like Central Park—in that it’s a large oasis in the middle of the city—but with multiple palaces and a residing imperial family who live there. Oh, and it’s filled with lush, Zen-inducing vegetation and beautiful Japanese architecture. And while the buildings aren’t open to the public for the most part, a long walk in the park will have you feeling sufficiently submerged in historical Tokyo.

__[Dover Street Market](http://ginza.doverstreetmarket.com/)__

By now, Rei Kawakubo’s shopping mecca has outposts in New York and London, but the original and best has been (and will always be) in Tokyo. Even Dior-ites can’t help but pay it a visit. The Ginza store is pretty much an art gallery for avant-garde fashion—just think of your haul of never-before-seen Sacai and Undercover as souvenirs.


[#image: /photos/54b9712bf026e0d339fb6860]||||||



__[The Palace Hotel](http://cntraveler.com/hotels/japan/tokyo/palace-hotel--tokyo)__

Located next to the serene [Imperial Palace Gardens](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/tokyo-imperial-palace) and close to Marunouchi Naka-Dori (Tokyo’s version of Madison Avenue), The Palace takes *omotenashi,*that inimitable brand of Japanese hospitality, very, very seriously. Throw in the whole view over the city and extremely lux rooms (extra-large, with balconies), and you’re pretty much in heaven. If it’s good enough for designer Raf Simons, it’s good enough for us.


 
__[Tsukiji Jisaku] (http://www.jisaku.co.jp/)__  

Even if Dior doesn’t bring you, Tsukiji Jisaku is worth visiting for a traditional, super luxurious lunch. Instead of chairs, you’ll sit on silk floor pillows, wear slippers (forget wearing shoes to impress—you’ll be removing them at the door), and eat mountains of authentic Japanese dishes as you admire a tableside koi pod.


[#image: /photos/54b9712f040ea11752369deb]||||||



__[Tokyu Hands] (http://cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/tokyu-hands-shibuya)__

Okay, so maybe this isn’t so Dior, but [Tokyu Hands](http://www.tokyo-hands.co.jp/foreign.html) is totally worth a visit if you’re on the hunt for any of the kitschy Japanese toys, stickers, and erasers that haunt your childhood dreams. Think of it as an extremely chic Walmart (they have everything). We loaded up on sushi erasers, Hello Kitty agendas, and about a million pages of teeny-weeny stickers.


__Trump Room__ 

Trump Room in Shibuya is Tokyo’s ultimate hip dive bar. Come to party with the city’s fashionable elite and stay for the totally amazing velvet, gilt, and chandelier-bedecked decor. Insider tip: Wear as eccentric a costume as you can dream up. You’ll know why when you arrive.


[#image: /photos/54b9712ff026e0d339fb687e]||||||





__Esprit Dior Exhibition__

The exhibit closed earlier this month (all the info is still available for perusal on [Dior’s site] (http://www.dior.com/couture/en_us/the-house-of-dior/exhibitions/esprit-dior)), but the Ginza show gave a real sense of just how linked the French house and Japan really are. Patrick Demarchelier’s photographs prove that Japan served as endless inspiration for Christian Dior himself, and now Simons is plumbing the country, too—hence his decision to show the pre-fall collection in a Sumo stadium in Tokyo.


__Sasha Kanetanaka__

Located between Céline and Louis Vuitton in Shimbashi, Sasha Kanetanaka is a more modern take on Japanese cuisine. Look out over a rock and moss garden as you indulge in sea bream, matcha green tea-flavored dumplings, and roast duck in the minimal space.

__More from The Coveteur:__  
[Inside the Closet of Mademoiselle Yulia](http://www.thecoveteur.com/mademoiselle-yulia/)  
[Backstage at the Dior Pre-Fall 2015 Show](http://www.thecoveteur.com/dior-tokyo-pre-fall-2015/)  
[Inside the Closet of Betty Halbreich](http://www.thecoveteur.com/betty-halbreich/)

fields.name: The Coveteur
fields.shortBio: [The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture.
fields.bio:
[The Coveteur](http://www.thecoveteur.com/) began as a passion project exploring the homes and closets of global street style stars and tastemakers, and has evolved into exploring all things behind-the-scenes: lifestyle, fashion, and culture. With an emphasis on highly personalized curation, The Coveteur goes one step further in examining the creative process, inspiration and influence of the individuals who are defining the zeitgeist of our times.

Founded by Stephanie Mark and Jake Rosenberg in 2011, The Coveteur pulls back the curtain on heretofore unseen adventures in style, travel, arts and culture and exposes what you’ve always wanted to see: an intimate and voyeuristic look at today's influencers.

cheatSheet.dek: Come to Tokyo for the sushi and stay for the soba. From preferred texture to temperature, there's a noodle shop and sake pairing for every palette.

items.dek: This unfettered soba shop is a sort of locals secret.
Stop by Honmura An for the chilled soba, made with light buckwheat noodles.
A 90-minute train ride from central Tokyo, Sawanoi is a sake factory and tasting house.
Top-quality soba in a quaint wooden house tucked away on a residential side street.
This sake bar promises a quality and thorough tasting of up to 100 variations.
Chef Masaaki Narutomi is master of the buckwheat noodle at this three-table + countertop soba shop.

cheatSheet.dek: Tokyo is a mecca for the shopping enthusiast, from street style to designer chic.

items.dek: The gritty and lose street-chic brand from designer Junichi Abe.
Young designer Shuji Itai makes what might be the world’s best oxford shirt.
The mix at this boutique is avant-garde and never boring.
Find a mix of full blown athletic wear and edgy, practical metropolitan pieces.
A whistle-stop tour of the best crafts from all over Japan.
The clothes and accessories at this Tokyo original are clever and cheerful.

cheatSheet.dek: Old town Tokyo is a web of ancient temples and nameless shoe-box shops. Come for a walk through the cemetery naturally trellised in Cherry Blossoms before finding your inner zen in Tennoji Temple. For lunch, grab sushi-to-go and sit on the street curb to survey the passing crowds.

items.dek: At once ghostly and serene, the cemetery is marked by a natural canopy of cherry blossoms.
Meander the pedestrian only streets that mark this shopping quarter of Japanese handcraft.
The oldest temple in Yanaka and the official house of Bishamonten, god of bravery and resources.
Find reprieve from the urban craze in Tokyo's first public park.
Enjoy a coffee and rent a bike at this modernist concept store in old town Tokyo.
A lifestyle store with an emphasis on goods from local craftsmen: ceramics, stationary, linens.

miniGuides.dek: No visit to Tokyo is complete without a walk through the Shibuya-Harajuku-Minami Aoyama areas (the first two were the original ground zeros of Tokyo street style culture; the last is a tree-lined, upscale neighborhood with high-end boutiques). Orient yourself at Shibuya station and explore from here.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/548b4014860c74c1162c8f0e]|||Pay a visit to the serene Meiji Shrine, which sits just about Harajuku.|||


## EAT HERE

[Maru](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/tokyo/maru), on the northern edge of Minami Aoyama, is one of the very few izakayas in Tokyo that has an English menu; the crowd’s a good mix of expats and locals. Head down the steep flight of stairs and order a selection of small dishes that might include lotus root salad, grilled mackerel, and corn tempura. Make sure to order a rice dish—the restaurant’s specialty. And if you can’t decide whether you want a rice ball, or sushi, or tempura, just get them all: the [Tokyu Food Show](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/tokyo/tokyu-food-show), in the basement floor of the Tokyu Department Store (connected to Shibuya station), one of the city’s best and most wide-ranging food halls, you can wander from counter to counter, picking whatever catches your eye. It’s a delicious (and affordable) way to sample some of the country’s huge array of cuisines.

## PLAY HERE

[Meiji Shrine](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/meiji-shrine), which sits just above Harajuku, isn’t the city’s oldest, but it’s one of its most beautiful, with an enormous torii marking its entrance and a long, gravelly path that cuts through a forest of pine trees so tall and dense and noise-blotting that you won’t be able to believe you’re still in Tokyo. If you come on the weekend in nice weather, you might be lucky enough to see a traditional wedding procession.

## EXPLORE HERE


Afterward, head down the hill and walk through the streets of Harajuku, where you’ll see teenagers dressed in outlandish outfits, preening for one another. Although this is now one of Tokyo’s wealthiest neighborhoods, it still retains many of its small, scrappy street-kid shops, as well as all the high-end boutiques by international labels and home-grown ones as well (of particular note: the streetwear line [Visvim](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/visvim), tucked off a side street, and the [Comme des Garcons](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/comme-des-garcons) concept stores located in the Gyre Building on Omotesando, the neighborhood’s main drag. Closer to Shibuya station, there’s an excellent art-book store, Libro, in the basement of department store [Parco](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/parco), along with Do, a concept store with well-chosen locally made goods run by the hotel Claska.
miniGuides.seoDescription: No visit to Tokyo complete without a walk through the Shibuya-Harajuku-Minami Aoyama areas.
miniGuides.socialDescription: No visit to Tokyo complete without a walk through the Shibuya-Harajuku-Minami Aoyama areas.

fields.name: Hanya Yanagihara
fields.shortBio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler* and the author of the novels *The People in the Trees* and *A Little Life* (March 2015). She is currently deputy editor of T magazine.

miniGuides.dek:
Tokyo is sprawling and confusingly laid-out, which means that it’s best to pick one or two neighborhoods per day so you can explore them at your own pace, meandering through their tiny streets at your leisure. 

Although much of the city dates from after the war, you can still sense ghosts of what Tokyo used to be: an overgrown fishing village consisting of webs of narrow alleys, and even now, you need only detour off a main drag to feel the essential hominess that the city still exudes.
miniGuides.body:
[#image: /photos/5493086475c4333528ffc316]||||||




## Day 1

__The neighborhood:__ Minami-Aoyama. This posh, pretty residential area south of Meiji Shrine, of the city’s most important, makes for a tranquil day of walking and shopping.

__Eat__

1) [__Kawakamian Aoyama.__](http://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/tokyo/kawakamian-aoyama) Top-quality soba in a quaint wooden house tucked away on a residential side street. There’s an English menu as well (3 Chome-14-1 Minamiaoyama, Minato-ku; 81 3-5411-7171).

2) [__Yoku Moku.__](http://cnt.conde.io/restaurants/tokyo/yoku-moku) The famous Japanese cookie brand is known for its sinfully buttery chocolate-dipped cigar-shaped pastries; have some (along with galettes and a selection of cakes) with the ladies who lunch at this iconic café—and make sure to buy a box or three to go (5-3-3 Minami Aoyama, Minato-ku; 03 5485 3321; yokumoku.co.jp)

__Shop__

1)	[__Undercover.__](http://cnt.conde.io/shops/tokyo/undercover) The ceiling of designer Jun Takahashi’s flagship store is covered with a field of lightbulbs; the clothes and accessories are just as clever and cheerfully avant-garde (5–3–18 Minami-Aoyama, Minato-ku; 81-3-3407–1232; undercoverism.com).

2)	[__Original Fake.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/original-fake) Highly collectible limited-edition t-shirts, figurines, and menswear by designer KAWS’ cult favorite streetwear brand (5-3-25 Minami-Aoyama, Minato-ku; original-fake.com).

__See__

[__1) Nezu Museum.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/nezu-museum) An excellent small museum of pre-modern Japanese and Asian art in all mediums, with interesting rotating exhibitions. Leave time to explore the small, beautifully maintained traditional Japanese garden (complete with teahouse) out back (6-5-1 Minamiaoyama, Minato-ku; 81 3-3400-2536; nezu-muse.or.jp).

__Stay__ 

The [**Park Hyatt Tokyo**](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/japan/kamitakada/park-hyatt-tokyo) (3-7-1-2 Nishi Shinjuku, Shinjuku-Ku; 81 3 5322 1234; Tokyo.park.hyatt.com)

[#image: /photos/548b400e860c74c1162c8ef0]||||||



## Day 2

__The neighborhood:__ Ginza. Tokyo’s answer to the Upper East Side has all the luxury brands you’d expect—Chanel, Hermes, etc.—but also some of the city’s most storied department stores and traditional shops. 

__Eat__

[__Ippoh.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/tokyo/ippoh) Tempura so delicate, flavorful, and light that it’ll upend everything you thought fried food tasted like (6-8-7 Ginza, Kojun Bldg. 5F, Chuo-Ku; 81-3-3289-5011; ippoh.com).

__Shop__ 

1)	[__Itoya.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/itoya) We may associate Japan with technology, but there’s perhaps no other country that loves paper—and the written word—as much as this one. This century-old paper goods store has floors and floors of greeting cards, stationery, pens, brushes, and, best of all, traditional Japanese paper, or washi: buy a cottony sheet or two as a souvenir (3-7-1 Ginza, Chuo-ku; 81 3-3561-8311).

2)	[__BALS Tokyo.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/bals-tokyo) Every home good you never knew you needed, much of it locally made. There’s a nice selection of everyday traditional cookingware, including iron pots, incense holders, and lacquer dishes (Ginza Velvia 4F, 2-4-6 Ginza, Chuo-ku; balstokyo.com).

3)	[__Kyukyodo.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/kyukyodo) Founded in 1663, this incense and paper goods store is older than the capital itself (Tokyo didn’t become the seat of the emperor until 1868). This always-bustling multi-level shop is the place to buy traditional stationery and, of course, incense, which can run from a few dollars into the thousands (5−7-4 Ginza, Chuo-ku; 81 3-3571-4429).

__Stay__

[**The Peninsula Tokyo**](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/japan/tokyo/the-peninsula-tokyo) 
(1-8-1 Yurakucho, Chiyoda-ku;
81 3-6270-2888; Tokyo.peninsula.com)

[#image: /photos/548b4009860c74c1162c8eb7]||||||



## Day 3

**The Neighborhood:** Roppongi. The city’s bar and nightlife district can also get overrun with tourists and expats. But come during the daylight and you’ll find a surprisingly laidback neighborhood with lots of old-fashioned shops.

__Eat__

1) [__Tofuya Ukai.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/restaurants/tokyo/tofuya-ukai-tokyo) A shrine to all things tofu, often rendered in ways you never imagined. A lunch here is delicious but lengthy—be prepared to spend at least three hours. The location—a traditional house with private tatami-floored rooms overlooking a carp pond—is as beautiful as the food (4-4-13 Shiba-Koen, Minato-ku; 81-3-3436-1028; ukai.co.jp).
Shop

2)	[__Mamegen.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/shops/tokyo/mamegen) The Japanese love to snack, and at this renowned shop you can find traditional snacks to munch on for days, including puffed rice crackers, crispy peas, and shrimp-flavored peanuts (1-8-12 Azabu-Juban, Minato-ku; 81-3-3583-0962; mamegen.com).

__See__

1)	[__Wako Works of Art.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/wako-works-of-art) Intellectually rigorous conceptualism from artists both foreign (Gerhard Richter) and local (Shizuka Yokomizo) (Piramide Building 3F, 6-6-9 Roppongi Minato-ku, +81 3 6447 1820, wako-art.jp).

2)	[__Take Ninagawa.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/take-ninagawa) A terrific small gallery specializing in works by emerging (and mostly Japanese) artists working across all mediums (2-12-4 1F, Higashi-Azabu, Minato-ku, +81 3 5571 5844, takeninagawa.com).

3)	[__Mori Musem of Art.__](http://www.cntraveler.com/activities/tokyo/mori-musem-of-art) A contemporary art museum in the sky with an eclectic range of shows; their triennial exhibit of Japanese art is particularly strong and always worth a visit (6-10-1 Roppongi, Minato-ku; 03-5777-8600; mori.art.museum).

[#image: /photos/548b4009860c74c1162c8eb4]||||||
