fields.name: Hanya Yanagihara
fields.shortBio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler.*
fields.bio: Hanya Yanagihara is the former editor-at-large at *Conde Nast Traveler* and the author of the novels *The People in the Trees* and *A Little Life* (March 2015). She is currently deputy editor of T magazine.

featuredPlays.name: Tomio Koyama Gallery
featuredPlays.description: You'll find a cluster of several of Tokyo's best contemporary galleries in this warehouse space not far from the Museum of Contemporary Art—it's actually part of an active warehouse, so follow the signs to the freight elevator that leads to the galleries. Tomio Koyama represents over fifty Japanese and international artists, including two of Japan's current stars—Takashi Murakami and Yoshitomo Nar—while the Taka Ishii gallery downstairs represents Nobuyoshi Araki, who has been photographing the underside of Tokyo for decades.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Murakami fans will want to check out these galleries, which are housed in an active warehouse.

featuredPlays.name: Meiji Jingu
featuredPlays.description: Leave the bedlam of Harajuku behind and walk to Meiji Shrine, which is dedicated to Emperor Meiji (1852-1912). Pass through the giant cypress gate (or torii) at the back of Harajuku Station and walk along the wide gravel path. The shrine is an impressive sight—austere wooden buildings surrounded by greenery. On a quiet afternoon it can feel a long way from Tokyo. Meiji Jingu is a popular place to get married; on the weekends you're likely to see a wedding party in traditional outfits.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: A peaceful, wooded haven dedicated to Emperor Meiji that feels far from Tokyo's bustle.

featuredPlays.name: Nezu Museum
featuredPlays.description: This venerable old museum was given new life recently, as they reopened in impressive new facilities designed by architect Kengo Kuma. The Nezu's huge collection of pre-modern art from Japan, China and elsewhere in Asia includes more than 7,000 pieces—chiefly paintings, calligraphy, ceramics, and sculpture. After you've perused the indoor exhibition rooms you can admire the sculptures scattered throughout the extensive wooded garden area, and perhaps stop in the museum café for a sandwich and a matcha latte.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: More than 7,000 pieces comprise this collection of pre-modern art from Japan, China, and elsewhere.

fields.title: [Nezu Museum](http://www.nezu-muse.or.jp)
fields.caption: Venture outside of Tokyo’s hectic city center and you’ll find this peaceful retreat, which opened in 1941 at the former home of Japanese industrialist Nezu Kaichiro. The museum itself holds many treasures, including calligraphy scrolls, bamboo crafts, and paintings. However, if it’s _amour_ that you’re after, meander through the institution’s manicured grounds. As you walk along a cobblestone path, you’ll see quiet ponds, greenery, a few small teahouses, and little else to distract you from your beloved.

featuredPlays.name: Edo-Tokyo Open-Air Architectural Museum
featuredPlays.description: This complex is less a museum than a whole day out. Earthquakes, firebombing, and rampant development have left few examples of old architecture in Tokyo, but in 1993 the Tokyo government set aside about seventeen acres for this collection of historic buildings, which range from farmhouses and soy-sauce shops to private homes and public bathhouses. They were all saved from demolition and relocated to this fascinating outpost of the central Edo-Tokyo museum. Among the highlights: the home of much-admired Modernist architect Kunio Mayekawa.
featuredPlays.shortDescription: Seventeen acres of historic Tokyo including, farmhouses, soy-sauce shops, and public bathhouses.

eat.body:
Buzzy salad chain Sweetgreen arrived on the healthy-fast-food scene in 2007 and has since built up a very loyal fan base that's willing to wait on very long lines. This past summer, the D.C. upstart—launched by three college buddies—earned even more cool cred when it opened a shop in New York's [NoMad hotel](http://www.cntraveler.com/hotels/north-america/united-states/the-nomad-new-york-new-york), inspiring articles everywhere from the [New York Times](http://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/28/dining/sweetgreen-a-salad-chain-is-coming-to-manhattan.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1&) to [Serious Eats](http://newyork.seriouseats.com/2013/09/sweetgreen-nomad-best-salad-manhattan-nyc.html). Nicolas Jammet is one of the company's young co-CEOs, and he not only has a knack for salad, but he has the restaurant business in his blood. His parents used to own La Caravelle, a New York institution until it closed in 2004, and Nicolas worked as an intern at several eateries, including our own Condé Nast cafeteria. So when Jammet told us he was traveling to Tokyo, we wanted to hear about what kinds of restaurants and experiences would catch the attention of a 28-year-old food mogul. Here's what he found…





[#image: /photos/53da913f6dec627b149f37bb]||||||

 



_Nicolas Jammet is cofounder and co-CEO of Sweetgreen. Follow him at          [@nicjammet](https://twitter.com/nicjammet) or [@sweetgreen](https://twitter.com/sweetgreen)._







 

When I was younger, my parents fell in love with Japan, and they'd return from their many trips with incredible stories about the culture and cuisine. I decided to finally travel there this year with my twin brother, Patrick. We spent the weeks leading up to the trip researching and getting tips from friends who had visited or lived there. I've included some highlights from our incredible ten-day trip.










## [Gogyo Ramen](http://www.ramendining-gogyo.com/index.html)


Many of my friends recommended this spot, so I made a point to visit. This place is famous for its kogashi ramen that has a black broth made from burnt miso or soy sauce. The charring process gives the ramen a unique color and a smoky flavor unlike any other bowl of ramen I've had. All the other components, including the runny soft-boiled egg, the fatty slice of chashu pork, the naruto and nori only added to the incredible bowl. (1-4-36 NishiAzabu, Minato-ku, Tokyo; 075-254-5567).









[#image: /photos/53da913fdcd5888e145bd414]||||||
## [Hakone Jinja Temple & Hakone Open Air Museum](http://www.hakone-oam.or.jp/english/)


The city of Tokyo basically shuts down on January 1 and 2. Most of Tokyo's residents spend the first of the year at temple or outside the city. Pat and I decided to do the same with a two-day excursion to Hakone. Our favorite stop here was at the [Hakone Open Air Art Museum](http://www.hakone-oam.or.jp/english/), set in a valley among mountains. Apart from the various contemporary sculptures outside, there is a large Picasso collection. The most impressive structure was the Woods of Net by Tezuka Architects. Other highlights of this adventure included the Hakone Jinja Temple, natural hot springs, a cable car ride past Mount Fuji, a ride on Lake Ashinoko, and a traditional Japanese breakfast (Ninotaira, Hakone-Town, Kanagawa-Prefecture, 250-0493 Japan; 0460-82-1161).









[#image: /photos/53da913f6dec627b149f37db]||||||
## [Tsutaya Daikanyama Bookstore](http://tsite.jp/daikanyama/store-service/tsite-en.html)


This is a dream [book emporium](http://tsite.jp/daikanyama/store-service/tsite-en.html). Every city should have a mecca like this. Apart from the endless aisles of books on design, architecture, and food, there is also an incredible collection of literary magazines and vintage books, as well as a perfect café and bar on the second floor to sit, read and drink some tea. I came here planning to stay for 30 to 40 minutes perusing, and ended up spending almost four hours instead. I can't wait to go back (17-5 Sarugakucho, Shibuya-ku, Tokyo; 03-3770-2525).









[#image: /photos/53da913fdcd5888e145bd404]||||||
## [Tsukiji Fish Market & Sushi Dai](http://www.tsukiji-market.or.jp/tukiji_e.htm)


[Tsukiji](http://www.tsukiji-market.or.jp/tukiji_e.htm) is the most famous and largest of the fish markets in Tokyo. As one of the more [popular attractions to visit](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/50-things-to-see-in-asia-before-you-die_slideshow_item43_44), it was recommended to me by just about everyone. A family friend, Yukari, who is also a food and travel writer in Tokyo, toured us around the inner and outer market. If you can get a spot in the tuna auction before dawn, it's an impressive site to see. After seeing all the fish stalls, all you want to eat is sushi for breakfast, so that's what you do! The most famous is [Sushi Dai](http://www.tsukijigourmet.or.jp/22_sushidai/index.htm#02) (5-2-1 Tsukiji, Chuo, Tokyo 104-0045, Japan; 81-3-3542-1111).









[#image: /photos/53da913f6dec627b149f37bd]||||||
## [Sushi Shin](http://sushi-shin.com/)


Pat and I were on a clear mission to find and experience the best sushi we've ever had. We had a few sushi dinners during the trip, and all were amazing, but the standout was [Sushi Shin](http://sushi-shin.com/). The chef here used a special kind of vinegar in the sushi rice, which made it almost look like brown rice. Every piece was amazing, especially the otoro (4-18-20 Nishiazabu, Minato-ku, Tokyo; 03-5485-0031).









** **



**More on Japan:**



[The Best New Restaurants in Tokyo](http://www.cntraveler.com/food/2013/07/best-new-restaurants-2013/tokyo)



[Grand Tour of Asia: An Insider's Guide to the Ultimate Trip](http://www.cntraveler.com/grand-tour-of-asia)







[50 Things to Do in Asia Before You Die](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/03/50-things-to-see-in-asia-before-you-die)

eat.body:
[#image: /photos/53daa87f6dec627b149f9971]||||||

** You can't leave Tokyo without eating…**



 Soba (buckwheat noodles). In fact, you'll have a tough time leaving Japan without eating it at least once. Order a tempura lunch set (and you will, every day), and your tray comes piled high with cold, snappy noodles. Tokyo is sweltering and humid come summer, but a plate of chilled soba, often served with ice cubes mixed in, is the next best thing to climbing into the ice cream freezer at 7-Eleven.







**How to eat it**: Do not wear a white shirt. Your soba will be delivered to the table on a _zaru_ (bamboo tray), often with _nori_ (dried seaweed) sprinkled on top. Next to it will be a small cup of _tsuyu_ (a cold broth made from dried bonito flakes and soy sauce), an empty cup, a saucer with wasabi, and finely chopped _negi_ (scallion). Mix the tsuyu, wasabi, and negi in the cup; if you aren't used to spicy, go easy on the wasabi. If you're congested, it will clear you right up. Deftly use your chopsticks to pick up some soba noodles and then dip—don’t drown—your soba in the tsuyu. Lean over, open wide, and slurp heartily.







When you’ve nearly finished your soba, the waitstaff will bring over what looks like a lacquer teapot. It’s actually water from the pot in which the noodles where cooked. Hardcore soba lovers will pour it into their remaining tsuyu and drink it like soup.





[#image: /photos/53daa87fdcd5888e145c34a9]||||||

**How to order**: Like so many Japanese foods, this one is easy to order because its English name is Japanese. The menu will likely be in Japanese. Soba is often served as part of set meals, but if you want to order it a la carte, ask for "_zaru soba, onegai shimasu_" (“cold soba, please”). As soba broth is fish based, strict vegetarians will want to substitute soy sauce. Don't complicate things by trying to pantomime swapping soba broth for soy sauce, though; the soy sauce will already be on the table.







**How to pay**: The bill will be set discretely on your table after your order is relayed to the kitchen, but in the world's most polite country, this is in no way an attempt to rush you out of the restaurant. When you're ready to leave, just go to the cashier.







**Do you tip?** Tipping is not customary in Japan. If you leave money on the table, the waitstaff will try to give it back to you. Your polite thank you's throughout the meal are enough.



**Etiquette tip**: Leaning over your bowl and slurping the soba noisily is perfectly acceptable. You should inhale with gusto to cool down the noodles on their way from the plate to your mouth. Try not to cut the noodles with your teeth, and be careful not to let them slip from your mouth and splash back into the bowl. Do not douse your entire tray of soba with soy sauce; this is what the empty cup is for.











**More travel etiquette**:



[The One Dish You Should Never Order in Rome](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2014/05/the-best-food-in-rome)







[What Not to Do in Las Vegas](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/2013/12/what-not-to-do-in-las-vegas)



[What Not to Do in New York City](http://www.cntraveler.com/daily-traveler/new-york/2013/12/what-not-to-do-nyc-travel)



_Sophie Friedman is a manager with [Context Travel walking tours](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists/paul-bennett), a company chosen as one of [Condé Nast Traveler's top travel specialists](http://www.cntraveler.com/travel-tips/travel-specialists)._

We tapped Tokyo chef and _Food Sake Tokyo_ author Yukari Sakamoto for her guide to the city's best new restaurants—and her picks sound delicious. Drool over these recommendations of top ramen, tapas, and trendy spots, then read our full list of the [world's best new restaurants](/food/2013/07/best-new-restaurants-2013).





[#image: /photos/53ea89a3dd4d6a0b75ef7531]||||||

[#image: /photos/53ea89a3dd4d6a0b75ef7551]||||||

[#image: /photos/53ea89a3dd4d6a0b75ef7541]||||||

[#image: /photos/53ea89a2976f8f2d44d53116]||||||

[#image: /photos/53ea89a4976f8f2d44d5313a]||||||

[#image: /photos/53ea89a3976f8f2d44d53126]||||||



**The nominator:** Yukari Sakamoto



**Her credentials:** Tokyo-based chef, sommelier, and shochu adviser; author of _Food Sake Tokyo,_ a guide to the city’s restaurants and food halls (Little Bookroom, $30). Follow her on [foodsaketokyo.wordpress.com](http://foodsaketokyo.wordpress.com) and on Twitter [@yukarisakamoto](https://twitter.com/YukariSakamoto).


##### [

 Cicada

](http://www.tyharborbrewing.co.jp/en/cicada/)






**The scene:** This is the kind of easygoing restaurant you wish were in your neighborhood. The vibe is relaxed, the music is loungey, the service is friendly, and the menu is solid. Run by a former New Yorker, David Chiddo, it has room for about 50 and is in the Omotesando shopping district, just down the street from Comme des Garçons.



 **The food:** Mediterranean-influenced tapas and meats with an eclectic wine list. Really, though, you’re here for the beer. Craft beer is a trend in Tokyo, and Cicada is one of the few places that successfully pairs brews with food.



 **Dish to get:** The meze plate of cheese, meats, and dips served with flat bread (the selection changes weekly) and a glass of the on-tap Tokyo-brewed T.Y. Harbor (Minato-­ku, Minami-Aoyama 5-7-28; 81-3-6434-1255; entrées from $18).







 


##### La Sora Seed


**The scene:** It’s all drama at this thirty-first-floor space in the Oshiage district, where floor-to-ceiling windows offer views of the world’s largest communications tower, Tokyo Skytree.



 **The food:** Tokyoites used to journey four hours to chef Masayuki Okuda’s restaurant, Al-che-cciano, for Italian dishes made with Japanese farm products. Now they can eat his flavorful food, like bamboo shoot risotto with boar pancetta, roasted baby sweetfish, and red eggplants, right in town.



 **Dish to get:** Try the lunch buffet of vegetables served raw, steamed, and roasted. You might find eight types of heirloom tomatoes, steamed white sweet potatoes, and sautéed mushrooms. Just spritz them with salt water and they’re ready to savor (Sumida-ku, Oshiage 1-1-2, 31st floor; 81-3-5809-7284; set menus from $77).







 


##### Le Salon Jacques Borie


**The scene:** Classical music provides the sound track for this 35-seat salon on the fashion floor of Isetan, a premier department store in the shop- and bar-filled Shinjuku district.



 **The food:** French classics (quiche lorraine and sautéed foie gras) by one of Japan’s most famous French chefs, Jacques Borie, who oversaw Tokyo restaurants L’Osier and Shiseido Parlour.



 **Dish to get:** The main courses are terrific, but the real prize is Borie’s dessert wagon, which is piled with traditional pastries such as _vacherin meringue, tarte Tatin_, and _île flottante_, an airy meringue dotted with nuts. After, visit Isetan’s _depachika_, or basement epicurean floor, which has the city’s best selection of prepared and packaged foods (Shinjuku-ku, Shinjuku 3-14-1, Shinjuku Isetan 4F; 81-3-5363-5688; set menu, $58).







 


##### Menya Sumisu


**The scene:** At this bustling bare-bones 18-seat ramen joint in the residential Minami-Aoyama district, businessmen tuck paper bibs into their collars and slurp up noodles. Don’t expect finesse: The lighting is aggressively bright, and J-pop music blares from the speakers.



 **The food:** Why is this, of all of Tokyo’s many ramen shops, getting such rave reviews? Because of its chicken stock. While many ramen restaurants have turned to thick pork bone–based stocks, Menya Sumisu uses a very simple chicken stock. The result is a bowl of noodles that’s satisfying yet not at all heavy.



 **Dish to get:** Salt or soy sauce ramen: thin noodles with smoky grilled chicken and a chicken meatball studded with bits of crunchy cartilage (Minato-ku, Minami-Aoyama 2-2-15, Win Aoyama 1F; 81-3-3497-5828; ramen from $7).



 


##### [Da Olmo](http://www.da-olmo.com/)






**The scene:** A boisterous 24-seat restaurant on the first floor of an inconspicuous residential building in the business district of Kamiyacho. Service is excellent and crisp, and there’s a knowledgeable sommelier on staff.



 **The food:** Northern Italian cuisine is one of the hottest trends in Tokyo, and chef Yukihiro Kitamura has expertly wed its flavors with some classic Japanese ingredients, including creamy Pacific cod milt (which comes swirled with linguine) and germinated brown rice, which is used to produce a richly textured risotto.



 **Dish to get:** Tajima wagyu beef aged for eight weeks and sliced thin for a rich _carne salata_. Or get the rustic Bolognese, also made with Tajima wagyu, which is served atop hand-rolled Siena pici pasta (Minato-ku, Toranomon 5-3-9, 101 Zelkova 5 Bldg. 1F; 81-3-6432-4073; set menus from $65).







 


#####



 Ohara


**The scene:** These days, the city’s hottest food district is Arakicho, a maze of narrow streets near the bar-crowded Shinjuku area that are filled with small restaurants of exceptional quality. But even here, the exquisite 12-seat Ohara stands out. The hushed interior is designed with traditional _washi_ paper screens; it feels like a secret about to be discovered.



 **The food:** Traditional _kaiseki_ cuisine of seasonal ingredients served on tableware that varies with the season.



 **Dish to get:** The menu changes every two weeks or so, but recent favorites included an _owan_ (soup) course of _shinjo_ (shrimp dumpling)—fluffy fish paste studded with _hamaguri_ (clams)—in an aromatic broth. The meal ends with whisked matcha and handmade _wagashi_ (Shinjuku-ku, Arakicho 1-Banchi, Nakabayashi Bldg. 2F; 81-3-6380-5223; set menus from $63).







 


#####



 Udon Maruka






**The scene:** Join the long line of businessmen and local university students to grab one of the 29 stools at the communal table at this bright and spartan restaurant in Kanda, a district famous for its many used-book stores. Soon you’ll be slurping up udon noodles to a throbbing rock sound track. Around you, the air fills with steam from the large pots of boiling water in the open kitchen.



 **The food:** Udon restaurants are everywhere in Tokyo, but Udon Maruka has distinguished itself with its thick, chewy noodles and delicately seasoned broth. After finishing half of the noodles, sprinkle some yuzu vinegar over the rest for a tart and refreshing finish.



 **Dish to get:** The kake udon, or noodles in soup, and the squid-leg tempura, which is served overspilling its dish; you can ask for scissors to cut them into smaller pieces (Chiyoda-ku, Kanda-Ogawamachi 3-16-1, New Surugadai Bldg. 1F; 81-3-3294-1320; udon from $2).









[]()





Photographs of La Sora Seed and Le Salon Jacques Borie by Marie Takahashi









[#image: /photos/53e2dbfadddaa35c30f60aaa]|||A high-energy, 41-seat Manhattan space full of loud music, hipster diners, and food adventurers—it’s like a frat party in a Chinese take-out shop.
